entry.title: Re: Automatically plan production order after component a...
entry.content:
Hello @Jakobstrom 

I don't think you can do that automatically. Of course, you can use MRP exceptions and quickly identify supply/demand misalignments and act accordingly. However, those actions or remedies have to be done manually. The reason is that each time a human decision is needed.

What you are looking for is essentially putting MRP planning on its head. MRP tells you what you need to produce/purchase not what you can produce/purchase. MRP is demand driven. It looks at demand and builds a supply plan. It works top-down. It doesn't work bottom-up. It doesn't look at your components and tell you what you can produce with that. If you went bottom-up, you would end up with products that can be produced but that might not be needed in the first place. That is not the way to manage inventory.

Honestly, that is not the first time I hear this question. To me it is a telltale sign that the supply chain planning / management / integration is broken.

Best regards

Dominik Tylczynski

entry.title: SAP Business Network for Logistics 2510 – What’s New?
entry.content:
The latest October release for SAP Business Network for Logistics brings several updates in SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration aimed at refining the user experience and improving operational efficiency. With a focus on restructuring existing tools, enhancing usability, and providing better visibility into key processes, these changes address evolving needs in logistics and freight management.

In this blog post, we’ll provide an overview of the newly introduced features, ranging from improvements in dock appointment scheduling and dispute management to updates to application help and API documentation. Let’s take a closer look at what this release has to offer.

 

SAP Business Network Freight Collaboration

Application Help in SAP Help Portal has been restructured

In the application help on SAP Help Portal, the sequence of topics has changed to create a more natural order.

 

2026 Release schedule in out

The release schedule for 2026 is now available on the product page on SAP Help Portal.

 

Provider API for Order Events (FC): GEOLOC event type has been deprecated

In the ‘Provider API for Order Events (FC)’, the GEOLOC event type has been deprecated in the freight collaboration component.

 

API documentation now available in HTML version

The new API Documentation is now available in the HTML version on the product page. It consolidates content on public APIs and GTT backend service interfaces that were previously scattered across two guides.

 

‘Manage Integration Logs’ app: search on document ID (without requiring a timestamp) enabled

The ‘Manage Integration Logs’ app now allows users to search by document ID without requiring a timestamp. The ‘Received On’ filter has become optional.

Users now have the following search options:

  • Search by Document ID
  • Search by Received On
  • Search by Document ID and Received On

 

Cancellation of freight documents in external system

When the ordering party cancels a freight document in its external system that has been sent for confirmation to the carrier, the corresponding freight order is cancelled in the ‘Freight Orders for Confirmation’ app and the ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app.

Note that the freight order can be cancelled only when there is no active dispute or corresponding invoice document.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: new carrier filter and enhanced sorting

In the main view of the ‘Manage Gate Operations’ app, we introduced a new carrier filter, allowing users to streamline their workflow by focusing on specific carriers. Enhanced table sorting and grouping options provide greater flexibility in personalizing data presentation, improving efficiency and user experience.

 

Dock Appointment Scheduling: new event status filter

In the table view of the ‘Manage Dock Appointments’ app, we introduced a new event status filter, allowing users to easily sort and manage appointments based on their status. This enhancement improves efficiency by providing a streamlined way to access and organize appointment information.

 

Settlement: ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app: now showing document status ‘Uploaded’ and ‘Cancelled’

In the ‘Invoice Freight Documents’ app, in the worklist page, you can now view the document statuses ‘Updated’ and ‘Cancelled’ as a label in the worklist. When the ordering party updates a freight document in their external system, you can view the ‘Updated’ label for the freight document in the worklist. When the ordering party cancels a freight document in their external system, you can view the ‘Cancelled’ label for the freight document in the worklist.

 The labels also show on the detail pages of the freight document.

 

Settlement: ‘Manage Disputes’: new status introduced ‘In Error’

In the ‘Manage Disputes’ app, a new dispute status ‘In Error’ has been added. (see below).

 

Settlement: ‘Manage Disputes’ app: new tab ‘Error Logs’

An ‘Error’ message in the ‘Error Logs’ tab in the ‘Manage Disputes’ app indicates that there was a failure in the update of agreed charges in the external system. Shippers will thus know, in case charges have not been updated.

Additional details can be found in the error message detail view.

 

---------------------

The above summarizes the key innovations for 2510. We hope you enjoy the new capabilities. Thanks for reading the blog post and stay tuned! 

A full overview of the 2510 release can be found under the following link.

To learn more about SAP Business Network for Logistics visit SAP - Business Network for Logistics.

For further questions and feedback related to the blog, please check the Q&A area and feel free to post your questions in the link with the tag SAP Business Network for Logistics.

entry.title: Re: Restrict User from creating back date invoice for spe...
entry.content:
Hello @aakash96 

If your goal is to prevent users from creating invoices until checks or approvals are finished, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud offers standard options. It is recommended to implement the following.

Preliminary Billing and Workflow (recommended)

Allow users to create only Preliminary Billing Documents app

Configure approval workflow with app Manage Preliminary Billing Document Workflows.

Remove the Create Billing Documents App from end-user roles to ensure that only approved preliminary documents can be converted into final invoices.

Billing Block or Incompletion to implement Process Control

Set a default billing block on order or delivery types, releasing it after review.

Keep Incompletion Procedures active to prevent invoice generation until all required data, like FACe/DIR3, is completed.

Role Restriction (hard stop)

Restrict access to the invoice creation app, Create Billing Documents, to a small group of authorised users only.

Recommendation:
Use Preliminary Billing along with Workflow to ensure proper approval tracking and, optionally, combine it with billing blocks or incompletion steps to enforce data quality before invoicing.

With kind regards

Chuma

entry.title: Calculation % of Sales for each division and month without formula bar
entry.content:
Dear All,

I am currently facing challenges with creating a custom calculation in SAP Analytics Cloud. My objective is to calculate the percentage of Sales for each division for each month.

So far, I have successfully sum the monthly Sales values using the Aggregation function. In the next step, I need to compute a simple ratio:

(Sales / Total Sales) * 100

However, the output I receive is always 1, which indicates an issue with the calculation logic.

I am able to achieve the correct result using the formula bar, but this approach does not meet my requirements because I need to schedule the report in Excel format, and custom calculations created in the formula bar are not included in scheduled exports.

I would greatly appreciate any suggestions or best practices to resolve this issue.

Thank you in advance for your support.

entry.title: Why Devtoberfest keeps me coming back
entry.content:
Hello world, and happy Devtoberfest!

Since 2022, I’ve been taking part in SAP Devtoberfest. What started out as a fun experiment has quickly turned into a tradition that I look forward to each year.

Devtoberfest is much more than collecting points or badges. It’s about learning in a playful way, exploring new aspects of the SAP ecosystem, and feeling the great energy of the SAP Community. Each task, whether challenging or simple, brings something new. Sometimes a smile, sometimes an “aha” moment that finds its way into my daily work. The 2025 Devtoberfest is still running, and once again it has already given me many of those moments.

A personal highlight for me was being one of the winners in 2023. The prize trip took place in November 2024 and included the chance to attend ASUG TechConnect in West Palm Beach and to visit Disney World in Orlando together with the other winners and the SAP Developer Advocates. The time we spent together was inspiring and made the community spirit come alive.

None of this would be possible without the dedicated work of the SAP Developer Advocates and everyone supporting them behind the scenes. You create an event that connects developers around the world, motivates them, and makes learning fun. For that, I want to say a heartfelt thank you.

👉What about you? What has been your favorite Devtoberfest moment so far?

I’d love to hear how you are experiencing this year’s journey.

Best regards,
Sebastian

entry.title: SAP S/4HANA Implementation at Fergana Oil Refinery: Phased Digital Transformation in Emerging Market
entry.content:
1. Introduction: Digital Transformation in Emerging Markets

Digital transformation in emerging markets presents unique challenges that extend far beyond technical implementation. When we began implementing SAP S/4HANA at the Fergana Oil Refinery in Uzbekistan, we quickly realized that global best practices and the SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas approach require significant adaptation to local realities.

This article shares practical experience from implementation project at an enterprise with 4,500 employees, covering the full spectrum of modules SAP S/4 Hana: FI, CO, MM, SD, PP, PM, PS, TR and systems HCM, MDG, Solution Manager. Our experience offers valuable lessons for SAP professionals working on projects in emerging markets and raises important questions for the SAP Community about the balance between localization and standardization.

2. Project Context: Uzbekistan as an Emerging Market

In recent years, Uzbekistan has undergone large-scale economic reforms: liberalization of the currency market, digitalization of taxation (electronic invoices), and integration into global supply chains. However, the business environment still presents significant challenges:

  • Regulatory complexity: mandatory electronic invoices (e-SF), strict currency control, frequent changes to tax reporting requirements
  • Infrastructure limitations: unstable internet, limited pool of local IT specialists
  • Digital maturity: low level of computer literacy among users - many employees had never actively worked on computers before SAP implementation
  • Language requirements: documentation must be in Russian or Uzbek with notarized translations for legal purposes

Company Profile:

  • Over 4,500 employees at the Fergana Oil Refinery
  • Previous system: 1C Accounting (used only by the finance department, 25 accountants)
  • After SAP implementation: 400+ active users in finance, logistics, production, and maintenance

3. Project Timeline: Phased Approach

Given the risks inherent in implementations in emerging markets, we chose a cautious phased implementation strategy:

Figure 1. SAP S/4HANA Implementation Timeline at Fergana Oil Refinery

3.1. 2021: Main Implementation Phase

At this stage, we laid the project foundation, taking the SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas approach as our basis:

  • Fit-Gap Analysis: Conducted detailed analysis of gaps between standard SAP processes and local requirements
  • Deployment based on SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas: Used pre-configured processes as a starting point
  • Requirements Gathering and Design: Documentation of business processes and technical specifications
  • Infrastructure Setup: Initially deployed the system in the cloud due to server delivery delays
  • Development and Testing: System configuration and integration testing

3.2. 2022: Pilot Industrial Operation

This year became a turning point in the project. We launched the system in pilot industrial operation mode with parallel data entry:

  • Dual Data Entry: All transactions were entered in parallel in both 1C and SAP throughout the year
  • Continuous Training: Users underwent intensive training in specialized training classrooms at the plant
  • System Refinement: The system was improved based on real user feedback
  • Change Management: Key task - proving to users that SAP adds real business value
  • Process Validation: Monthly data reconciliation between systems to confirm correctness

This year became critically important for building user trust in the new system.

3.3. 2023: Production Launch and On-Premise Migration

January 1, 2023 - the key date of the project:

  • Production Operation: SAP S/4HANA and HCM systems were officially put into production operation
  • Infrastructure Migration: Servers were migrated from the cloud platform to proprietary equipment physically located at the plant
  • 1C Shutdown: Legacy system was decommissioned
  • Complete Transition: All business processes are performed exclusively in SAP

3.4. 2023-2025: Continuous Improvement

From the moment the system was put into production operation, the continuous development phase began:

  • Monthly Releases: Over 3 years, we implemented improvements and enhancements through regular releases
  • Change Requests: Processing and implementation of requests from business users
  • Process Optimization: Continuous improvement of business processes based on feedback
  • Best Practices Creation: Documentation of replicable solutions for the group of companies
  • Horizontal Rollout: Deployment of SAP solutions to other holding enterprises

4. Final System Architecture Overview

After four years of phased implementation and continuous development, we built a comprehensive integrated landscape that reflects our complete digital transformation journey - from basic ERP modules to a full-scale enterprise ecosystem connecting business management, shop floor operations, and regulatory compliance systems (as shown in Figure 2).

Figure 2. SAP System Landscape Architecture at Fergana Oil Refinery

Four-layer enterprise architecture integrating SAP S/4HANA core modules (FI, CO, MM, SD, PP, PM, PS, TR, HCM, MDG) with operational systems (MES, PIMS). The architecture supports 400+ active users, processes 150+ daily shipments, and enables real-time data visibility from shop floor to executive dashboards.

4.1. Architecture Layers

Layer 1: Business Intelligence

  • SAP Analytics Cloud - Business Intelligence & Reporting Platform providing real-time dashboards and analytics for all management levels

Layer 2: Additional SAP Systems

  • SAP HCM - Human Capital Management (Organizational Management, Personnel Administration, Time Management, Payroll)
  • SAP MDG - Master Data Governance ensuring data quality and consistency across the enterprise
  • SAP Solution Manager - Application Lifecycle Management and system monitoring

Layer 3: SAP S/4HANA Core

  • SAP S/4HANA In-Memory Computing Platform managing core business processes:
    • FI/CO (Financial Accounting & Controlling): Local GAAP, IFRS, Tax Accounting
    • MM/SD (Materials Management & Sales Distribution)
    • PP (Production Planning)
    • PM (Plant Maintenance)
    • PS (Project System)
    • TR (Treasury)

Layer 4: Integration Layer

  • SAP PI/PO (Process Integration/Orchestration) - enabling seamless data exchange:
    • SAP ↔ SAP: RFC, BAPI, CDS Views, SAP PO
    • SAP ↔ Non-SAP: IDoc, OData, REST API, SAP CPI
  • Data Transfer Frequency: Real-time for critical transactions / Batch (scheduled) for analytics

Layer 5: Operational Systems

  • MES (Manufacturing Execution System) - shop floor control & production data collection
  • PIMS (Plant Information Management System) - production planning & optimization determining what products to produce, which crude to process, and optimal refinery unit loading to maximize margin

Layer 6: Non-SAP Systems

  • 1C - Legacy Accounting System
  • ACS - Advanced Control Systems for security & access management
  • Legacy Systems - Custom Applications

This architecture enabled the adaptation of SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas to local regulatory requirements while maintaining system stability and upgrade compatibility. The integration layer proved crucial for connecting enterprise systems with operational platforms and external regulatory portals, supporting real-time data synchronization across the entire business ecosystem.

5. Key Challenge: Adapting SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas to Local Realities

This is perhaps the most important lesson of the project: the SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas approach, despite its excellence for standardization, requires significant adaptation for emerging markets.

We initially planned to maximize the use of standard SAP processes, but quickly discovered that local regulatory requirements and business practices require substantial customizations.

5.1. Areas Requiring Significant Enhancements

Sales and Distribution Management (SD)

  • Integration with Automatic Scales: Connection of truck scales for automatic weight capture and elimination of human factor
  • Multi-Stage Approval Process: Shipment control at each stage with participation of various services
  • Specific Documentation: Localized forms of waybills and accompanying documents
  • Security Control: Integration with access control and pass systems

Materials Management (MM)

  • Custom MRP Logic: Specific material requirements planning for refinery processes
  • Unique Procurement Processes: Adaptation to local tender and approval requirements

Finance (FI/CO)

  • Integration with e-SF service faktura.uz: Automatic real-time invoice submission
  • Bank Statements: Automatic import and reconciliation of statements from local banks
  • Multi-Currency Accounting: Parallel accounting in sums and dollars with automatic revaluation
  • Localized Management Reporting: Specific reports for credit management, cash flow, profitability analysis

Regulatory Reporting

  • Tax Forms: Automated various forms for different types of taxes and fees
  • Statistical Reporting: Mandatory forms for the State Statistics Committee
  • Industry Reporting: Specialized reporting

5.2. Our Dilemma: Standardization vs. Localization

Throughout the project, we constantly balanced between two approaches:

Arguments for Standardization:

  • Simplification of future upgrades
  • Reduction of support costs
  • Use of global best practices
  • Ability to receive support from SAP

Arguments for Localization:

  • Compliance with mandatory regulatory requirements
  • Reflection of real business processes
  • Increased system adoption by users
  • Competitive advantages through process optimization

5.3. Our Approach: Balanced Strategy

We developed a principle: customize only where absolutely necessary, but document each deviation and maintain upgrade compatibility.

Practical Rules:

  • If standard SAP functionality exists - we use it
  • If minor adjustment is required - we apply configuration
  • Only critically important deviations are implemented through development
  • All customizations are documented with business justification
  • We use enhancement spots and BAdI to maintain upgrade compatibility

Result: We created a set of replicable solutions that are now successfully applied at other enterprises of the group of companies, proving the correctness of the chosen approach.

6. Change Management: The Path of Digital Transformation

The transition from 1C to SAP turned out to be not just a technical task - it was a large-scale cultural transformation affecting hundreds of employees.

6.1. Main Challenges

Low Level of Digital Literacy

  • Many employees had never seriously worked on computers
  • Only 25 accountants in the finance department used 1C
  • After SAP: 400+ users from all departments (logistics, production, maintenance, finance, planning)

Resistance to Change

  • Initial reaction: "Why do we need this? 1C worked fine!"
  • Fear of complexity: "The system is too complex, we won't manage"
  • Attachment to familiar processes: "We've always worked this way"
  • Productivity anxiety: "This will slow down our work"

Inter-Departmental Barriers

  • Finance department feared loss of control over data
  • Lack of cross-functional collaboration culture

6.2. Our Change Management Strategy

Year of Pilot Industrial Operation with parallel data entry (2022)

This was a key strategic decision. We did not force a sharp transition but gave users a whole year to adapt:

Dual Data Entry Process:

  • All transactions were recorded in parallel - in both 1C and SAP
  • Users saw daily that data in both systems matched
  • Trust in SAP's accuracy and reliability gradually grew
  • 1C served as a "safety net" during the learning period

Why It Worked:

  • Reduction of user risks and fears
  • Building trust through data transparency
  • Ability to learn from mistakes without critical consequences
  • Natural learning curve without pressure

6.3. Continuous User Training

We created a comprehensive training program:

Physical Infrastructure:

  • Specialized training classroom on plant premises
  • 20 personal computers for effective training
  • Equipment for group sessions

Training Program:

  • Initial intensive training: 1 month of training for each user group
  • On-the-job training: Constant support throughout 2022
  • Role-oriented approach: Different training programs for finance, logistics, and production staff
  • Key Users: Designation of key users in each area as change agents

Materials:

  • All documentation in Russian or Uzbek
  • Video instructions for self-study
  • Quick reference guides
  • Interactive simulations

6.4. Demonstrating Value, Not Imposing

Instead of coercion, we showed concrete benefits:

For Logistics:

  • Real-time inventory visibility
  • Elimination of need to call warehouse to check stock levels

For Procurement:

  • Electronic approvals instead of paper documents
  • Reduction of approval cycle from days to hours

For Sales Department:

  • Electronic shipment approvals instead of paper documents
  • Automation of pass regime
  • Integration with truck scales
  • Customer notifications about shipments via Telegram bot

For Production:

  • Automated material requirements planning
  • Reduction of time for production order preparation
  • Automation of production order entry

For Finance:

  • Automatic bank statement reconciliation
  • Saving 3 days of manual work monthly

For Management:

  • Real-time monitoring dashboards
  • Instant access to data instead of waiting for monthly reports

Critical Milestone:

By the time 1C was shut down on January 1, 2023, most users had not only mastered SAP but actively preferred working in the new SAP system, confirming the success of our change management strategy.

7. Results: Measurable Improvements

After two years of productive operation, we can provide concrete transformation figures:

7.1. Operational Metrics

Financial Period Close

  • Was (1C): 25 working days
  • Became (SAP): 5 working days
  • Improvement: 80% reduction
  • Factors: automated postings, parallel accounting, closing controls

Accounting Entry Automation

  • Was: 100% manual entry of all postings in 1C
  • Became: 90% automation through integrations and templates in SAP
  • Result:
    • Sharp reduction in errors (from 8% to 0.5%)
    • Freeing up accountant time for analytical work
    • Real-time postings

Shipment Processing

  • Was: average time 16 hours with manual document processing
  • Became: up to 8 hours average shipment time
  • Improvement: 50% acceleration
  • Throughput increase: from 100 to 200+ trucks per day

7.2. Personnel Productivity

Accounting Transformation:

  • Was: 25 employees, 90% of time on data entry
  • Became: 15 employees, 60% of time on analysis
  • Staff reduction: 40% through natural attrition (no layoffs)
  • Qualitative shift: from bookkeepers to business analysts

Digitalization Expansion:

  • Was: 25 system users (finance only)
  • Became: 400+ active users across all departments
  • Significance: involvement of all key business processes in a unified system
  • Cultural impact: organization became data-driven

Employee Time Reallocation:

  • Finance: 40% of time switched from entry to analysis
  • Procurement: 60% reduction in cycle from request to order
  • Logistics: 75% reduction in document processing time
  • Production: 50% reduction in planning time

7.3. Qualitative Improvements

Data Transparency

  • Single source of truth for all business processes
  • Real-time data visibility for management
  • 95% reduction in data discrepancies between departments
  • Ability to trace any transaction from start to finish

Compliance

  • 100% timely submission of mandatory reporting
  • 90% reduction in fines and audit remarks
  • Full compliance with currency control requirements

Decision-Making Quality

  • Transition from intuitive to data-driven decisions
  • Analytical dashboards for all management levels
  • Scenario analysis capability
  • Forecasting based on historical data

7.4. Scalability and Development

Solution Rollout:

  • Solutions are successfully being rolled out to other enterprises of the group of companies
  • Internal expertise created: team of 12 SAP specialists
  • Documented best practices developed, applicable at similar enterprises
  • SAP competence center created to support the entire group of companies

Continuous Development:

  • Monthly releases with improvements
  • Backlog of change requests in SAP Solution Manager system, users themselves register change requests
  • Regular user satisfaction surveys
  • Continuous training program for new employees

8. Lessons Learned: What's Important to Know

8.1. SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas is a Starting Point, Not a Final Solution

Our main lesson: standard SAP solutions must adapt to local realities, not vice versa.

In emerging markets, it's critical to consider:

  • Unique regulatory requirements with no analogues in Western markets
  • Business processes shaped by the local economic environment
  • Organization's digital maturity level and readiness for change
  • Infrastructure constraints (internet, power supply, technical resources)

Practical advice: Start with SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas, but plan time and resources for deep fit-gap analysis and localization. Document each deviation from standard with clear business justification.

8.2. Invest in Change Management - It's 50% of Success

The year of parallel operation was an expensive decision but absolutely justified:

  • Avoided project failure risk
  • Built user trust in the system
  • Ensured smooth transition without disrupting business processes

Especially critical for environments with:

  • Low digital literacy
  • Strong attachment to legacy systems
  • Lack of experience with enterprise systems
  • Cultural resistance to change

Practical advice: Don't underestimate the cultural component of transformation. Allocate at least 20% of the project budget to change management. Parallel launch for 6-12 months is the best investment for complex environments.

8.3. Infrastructure Flexibility is a Strategic Advantage

Our "cloud to on-premise" approach proved to be the right strategy:

Cloud Start Advantages:

  • Quick launch without waiting for equipment
  • Ability to scale resources during peak periods
  • Access for international consultants without complex VPN setup
  • Time for thorough local infrastructure planning

On-Premise Migration Advantages:

  • Operational cost reduction: payback in 20 months
  • Full control: availability, security, backup management
  • Data sovereignty: critical for strategic industries
  • Performance: elimination of network delays, especially important with unstable internet

Practical advice: Consider a hybrid approach for complex projects in emerging markets. Cloud provides speed of start, on-premise provides long-term efficiency.

8.4. Documentation is the Foundation of Sustainability

We maintained strict documentation of all deviations from SAP standard:

Critically important for:

  • Future upgrades: understanding which customizations need testing
  • Knowledge transfer: onboarding new team members
  • Solution rollout: deployment at other enterprises
  • Support: quick problem diagnosis
  • Audit: proof of technical decision validity

Our documentation standard includes:

  • Business justification for each customization
  • Technical specifications in Russian
  • User instructions in Uzbek or Russian
  • Video materials for key processes
  • Integration and data flow diagrams

Practical advice: Don't save on documentation. Investment in quality documentation pays back many times over in support and scaling.

8.5. Build Internal Expertise from Day One

Critical mistake of many projects: complete dependence on external consultants.

Our approach:

  • Trained 12 promising IT specialists without SAP experience
  • Invested in their deep training (SAP Learning Hub, certifications, mentoring)
  • Each external consultant worked in pairs with 2-3 local specialists
  • By launch time, 80% of knowledge was transferred to the internal team

Result:

  • Full autonomy in system support
  • Ability to develop the system independently
  • Low staff turnover (team stable for 3+ years)
  • Team became competence center for the group of companies

Practical advice: View the project as an investment in people, not just technology. The internal team is a long-term asset that continues to deliver value for years after launch.

9. Applicability to Other Markets

Our experience is directly applicable to a wide range of emerging economies with similar characteristics:

9.1. Central Asia (Kazakhstan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan)

Common Characteristics:

  • Similar regulatory requirements (post-Soviet legislation)
  • Common business culture and mentality
  • Similar infrastructure challenges
  • Comparable level of digital maturity

Applicable Solutions:

  • Electronic reporting and integrations with tax authorities
  • Currency control and multi-currency accounting
  • Approaches to training users with low digital literacy
  • Change management strategies in traditional cultures

9.2. Africa, Middle East

Common Challenges:

  • Unstable infrastructure (internet)
  • Complex regulatory environment
  • Multi-language requirements
  • Cultural resistance to change

Applicable Solutions:

  • Cloud/on-premise strategy for flexibility
  • Robust integrations accounting for channel instability
  • Multi-level training programs

9.3. Latin America

Common Characteristics:

  • Frequent changes in tax legislation
  • Electronic reporting systems
  • Inflationary environment and currency risks

Applicable Solutions:

  • Flexible localizations for quick adaptation to legislative changes
  • Automated integration with government portals
  • Multi-currency accounting and inflation protection mechanisms

9.4. Value for Global SAP Partners

Companies working with clients in emerging markets can extract valuable lessons:

Project Methodology:

  • How to adapt global solutions to local specifics
  • How to balance standardization and customization
  • How to build realistic timelines considering local factors

Working with People:

  • How to build change management in cultures with low digital maturity
  • How to effectively transfer knowledge in multicultural teams
  • How to create sustainable internal expertise

10. Conclusion and Questions to SAP Community

The SAP S/4HANA implementation at the Fergana Oil Refinery proved that comprehensive digital transformation is possible even in the most challenging conditions of emerging markets - but requires:

✓ Flexibility in approaches - readiness to adapt global standards to local realities
✓ Patience and investments - especially in user training and change management
✓ Balance of standardization and localization - customize only what's necessary, documenting each deviation
✓ Long-term strategy - focus on sustainability and scalability, not just quick launch
✓ Building internal expertise - investing in people as a key success factor

Results of Our Transformation:

  • 80-85% reduction in financial closing time
  • 400+ users involved in digital processes (vs. 25 in legacy system)
  • 90% accounting posting automation
  • Solution replicability to other enterprises of the group of companies
  • 12 SAP specialists - internal SAP competence center

Questions to SAP Community:

I would like to hear your opinions and experience:

  1. Localization vs. Standardization
    How do you manage the balance between adhering to SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas and adapting to local requirements in emerging markets? What criteria do you use for customization decisions?
  2. Successful Adaptation Examples
    What successful cases of SAP Model Company for Oil & Gas adaptation in emerging markets can you share? Which best practices proved most effective?
  3. Change Management in Complex Environments
    What approaches do you use for change management in organizations with low digital literacy? How do you overcome cultural resistance?
  4. Building Internal Expertise
    How do you organize knowledge transfer from external consultants to the internal team? What retention strategies work in emerging markets?
  5. Infrastructure Strategies
    What is your experience with choosing between cloud and on-premise solutions in regions with limited infrastructure?

I'd be happy to discuss our experience, answer questions, and learn about your projects. Let's learn from each other and create a community of experts on SAP implementations in emerging markets!

About the Author:

SAP Department Head with 15+ years of experience in SAP solution implementation and support. Expert in SAP S/4HANA, HCM, GRC, Solution Manager. Led a comprehensive digital transformation project at Fergana Oil Refinery, built a team of SAP support specialists, and developed replicable SAP solutions for the group of companies. Specialization: implementations in emerging markets, change management, building competence centers.

entry.title: Try UI theme designer for SAP BTP Cloud Foundry environment with a SAP Build Work Zone trial account
entry.content:
Try UI theme designer for SAP BTP, Cloud Foundry environment with a SAP Build Work Zone trial account

UI theme designer exists on different stacks: SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, SAP BTP Neo, SAP S/4HANA, and even SAP NetWeaver Java. Theming on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry is most actively developed, usually gets features first, and promises the least hassle – as it is a cloud service operated by SAP. However, you may not have access to the theming service on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, which is part of the different SAP Build Work Zone offerings.

In this blog, I want to show how you can use a SAP Build Work Zone trial account to try out theming on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry. No credit card required. You will not be able to publish themes in that infrastructure, but that is unnecessary (you wouldn't be able to consume them afterwards anyways): you can still export them and then use them wherever you need it – import them in your theme designer on a different stack, or even serve the compiled CSS files yourselves.

From trial to theming

The idea is to request a SAP Build Work Zone Trial Account, follow the "Build a Business site using SAP Build Work Zone" workbook until you have a running SAP Build Work Zone instance, and navigate to the UI theme designer from there. Let's dive in step by step:

1: Request the SAP Build Work Zone Trial

To request the trial, first navigate to https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/workzone/trial.html . You can create a free account if you don't already have one.

Once you're there, press "Try now" to start your free trial of SAP Build Work Zone:

01: Press "Try now"

A dialog opens that shows you your personalized credentials. Press "Click here to start your basic trial!". A new tab will open, leaving the dialog with the credentials visible, so you can copy&paste them later from there.

02: Remember your credentials, then press "Click here to start your free trial"

2: Open the lobby from the workbook

A new tab with a login screen opens. Enter the credentials from the dialog and press "Continue":

03: Enter your credentials, then press "Continue"

Now you're at the workbook selection screen, and have one workbook you can select. Press "Basic Trial - SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition":

04: Press "Basic Trial - SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition"

This leads you to an overview of the workbook. To start it, press "Start Workbook":

05: Press "Start Workbook"

The workbook is long (~50mins) and describes what you can do with SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition. To actually try it out, press "Lobby" in the prerequisites section of the overview:

06: Press "Lobby"

3: Create your SAP Build Work Zone trial instance

Now you're at the SAP Build Work Zone Lobby. There are a lot of existing projects, but you want to create a new one: press "Create" in the toolbar of the projects list:

07: Press "Create"

This opens a menu asking for the type of project you want to create. Press "Create" again, now in the menu:

08: Press "Create", now in the menu

A "Create Project" dialog opens, where you can select the objective you're after. Press "Business Site" to select that:

09: Press "Business Site"

Now you can press "Next" in the dialog's footer toolbar:

10: Press "Next"

You're at the 2nd step now, where you can select the type of Business Site you want to create. To create the SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, press "Manage Workspaces and Workpages":

11: Press "Manage Workspaces and Workpages"

Finally, you can press "Open" to create the instance:

12: Press "Open"

4: Open the UI theme designer

Now you have your own trial SAP Build Work Zone. To launch the UI theme designer from there, open the "Me Area". For that, press the avatar in the top-right corner:

13: Press the avatar in the top-right corner

In the "Me Area" menu, press "Theme Manager":

14: Press "Theme Manager"

A dialog opens that lets you (the admin) select the themes users of this SAP Build Work Zone instance would be able to select. Pres "Launch Theme Designer" to finally launch the UI theme designer:

15: Press "Launch Theme Designer"

5: Use the UI theme designer

Because this is a trial instance, you're not authorized to publish themes (so that they would appear for selection in the "Theme Manager" dialog above. That's not an issue, as you're more interested in the export functionality anyways. Confirm the warning that you're not authorized. Press "OK":

16: Press "OK"

Well done, you've managed to get your hands on a UI theme designer on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, with a SAP Build Work Zone trial account! Play around, create themes, export them, enjoy.

Recap

Admittedly, the steps are cumbersome, and you've opened five tabs in the process. But isn't it amazing that you can use the full UI theme designer on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry with that? Here's what you did:

  1. Request a SAP BTP Work Zone trial from https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/workzone/trial.html 
  2. Open the SAP BTP Work Zone lobby from the workbook
  3. Create your own SAP BTP Work Zone, advanced edition, trial instance
  4. Open the UI theme designer from the Theme Manager dialog
  5. Confirm the "not authorized to publish" warning and use the UI theme designer

Now it's your turn

Have you tried these steps? Did it work? Were you able to accomplish what you tried to achieve? What were the pain points? Where have you been stuck? Let me know in the comments!

Also: this blog post relies heavily on the SAP Build Work Zone trial instructions. It is very possible that these change over time. Please, if you notice that this blog post is outdated, let me know!

entry.title: Change Reason not visible in SAP SOM Subscription Contract / Change order
entry.content:
Dear Experts,

In SAP SOM, we have configured the BTMF process CHANGE_PRICE and assigned a Change Reason. We expect this to flow from the SOM to  CI/FI-CA Provider Contract (table DFKK_VT_I-CHRSN). While the CHANGE_PRICE action is visible under the Processes assignment block, we couldn't find the Change Reason visible in the subscription contract or the change order in SOM. Could you please confirm if this is standard system behavior, or if custom development is required to populate the Change Reason? 

Many thanks,

Al

entry.title: How can I track BOM change history without using ECM in S/4HANA Cloud?
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

In our S/4HANA Cloud system, we are facing an issue with BOM (Bill of Material) changes.

  • Sometimes other users modify the BOM, but I cannot easily see what was changed, when it was changed, or by whom.

  • I also need to check historical versions of the BOM for comparison or troubleshooting.

  • I know that Engineering Change Management (ECM) can control BOM changes using Change Numbers, but for our daily business it is not very convenient to use ECM for every small update.

My questions are:

  1. Is there any way to view BOM change logs (who changed, what component was added/removed/modified) without using ECM?

  2. Can I see the historical BOM structure or previous versions of the BOM in standard S/4HANA Cloud?

  3. Is there any Fiori app, CDS view, or report that can show BOM change documents automatically (STPO/STKO change history)?

  4. How do other companies monitor BOM changes to avoid silent modifications that nobody notices?

Any suggestions or best practices would be highly appreciated. Thank you!

Best regards,
Youzheng Tu

entry.title: Re: Deep-Dive: Cross-Company Topics In Controlling
entry.content:
Dear Dick,  

thank you for the helpful blog and valuable insights. 

If have two questions:

2. In the second example you show the classic RRICB process with invoice creation but it is a manual allocation. Is this process with invoice creation also possible with a allocation cycle via Universal allocations ?

entry.title: What is the difference in use of &variable and variable, for example &9000 and 9000?
entry.content:
Dear all,

I've been correcting a PCR and have just realized I'm unsure wether I should use &variable or directly grab the value of the variable.

Below I'm sending 2 examples for anyone to help me understand what might be going on with the use of &.

Example 1:

AMT= 9000
AMT?0
      *
      = 
            AMT=& 9001
            AMT?0
                    *
                     =
                          AMT= 9000
                          AMT?0

entry.title: Re: Exclude PSA from MRP Run
entry.content:
Good day @AdamHorne 

Thank you for your question.

Have a look at the following references for more details.

MRP Area, Excluding Plants, MRP Areas, and Storage Locations, Production Planning and Control

To summarise, in public cloud edition, you cannot exclude the Production Supply Area (PSA) itself from MRP directly. The reason is, MRP always plans at Plant & MRP area level. However, you can effectively prevent the PSA stock from being planned or replenished by adjusting the MRP control setting for that area. There are a few options you can explore:

Option 1; is to define a separate MRP Area and Deactivate MRP

  1. Use the Manage MRP areas configuration to create a dedicated MRP area for the PSA
  2. Assign the relevant storage location or PSA to this MRP area.
  3. In the MRP type for that MRP area, set it to ND, which means no MRP will be carried out.
    • This will ensure that your materials in the PSA are not planned or replenished by MRP runs.
  4. Finally ensure you save and activate the settings.

 

Option 2; is to use a Storage Location Excluded from MRP

If your PSA is linked to a specific storage location:

1. Open Manage Material Master Data.

2. Go to Plant/Storage Location MRP 2 view.

3. Set the indicator “Storage location excluded from MRP” to activate

This tells MRP to ignore any requirements or stock in that storage location. It is the simplest way when PSA= storage location.

 

Option 3; if your PSA is replenished through Control Cycle or kanban, you can stop replenishment by:

  • Setting the control cycle to Inactive, or
  • Using Replenishment Strategy = Manual.

This prevents the system from proposing supply for that PSSA

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: PDF auto open
entry.content:
As far as I know, this only happens when you use PDF export via PDF action button.

If you just want to create PDF without opening it, you could use PDF print instead of PDF export. Simply go to File => Print, and choose PDF printer.

By default you have Microsoft Print To PDF, which requires you name the PDF file and provide location for saving. Instead, you can install a PDF printer that supports auto print functionality, for example I use PDF24. With it, you can predefine:

  • location for PDF printing
  • name of the generated PDF file
  • what action to perform after printing (open folder, open file, none)

entry.title: Utilising the Define Eligibility for Onboarding Initiation Rule
entry.content:
When you initiate onboarding for internal employees the default process is for the employee’s employee central record to be updated before the onboarding process is initiated.  What is meant by that is a future date record is inserted into job and compensation information. Once the workflow is approved for this job/compensation information change then an onboarding process can be initiated.  Some customers like to see all of the data in MPH before a record is created in job and compensation. An onboarding process can still be triggered after MPH, please see this article.

In this blog we will look at how you can use the ‘Define Eligibility for Onboarding Initiation’ rule to send an internal employee or candidate direct to MPH, whilst still having the onboarding integration for other candidates.  In our example we want would like to be able to send all internal hires to go to MPH and for external hires on the same requisition to be able to initiate onboarding.  Up until now this has been a challenge for candidates on the same requisition.

The main driver for this configuration is we want to see all of the data in MPH for internals hires BEFORE we insert a future dated EC record.  To do this you will need to use a new rule in H1 2025 called ‘Define Eligibility for Onboarding Initiation’.  There is a prerequisite for this feature in that you need to have the new candidate workbench enabled.

Step 1 – Create the trigger logic

Create a new field on my candidate application called ‘Send to MPH’.  You can call this whatever you like but you need a picklist value to build a rule for the logic.  In recruitment you could build further logic to help you automate the process.  A certified recruitment consultant should do this.

<field-definition id="send_To_MPH" type="picklist" required="false" custom="true" public="false" readOnly="false" anonymize="false" forward-intact="false" sensitive="false">
    <field-label mime-type="text-plain"><![CDATA[Send to MPH]]></field-label>
      <field-label mime-type="text-plain" lang="en_US"><![CDATA[Send to MPH]]></field-label>
    <field-description><![CDATA[Send to MPH]]></field-description>
    <field-description lang="de_DE"><![CDATA[Send to MPH]]></field-description>
    <field-description lang="en_US"><![CDATA[Send to MPH]]></field-description>
    <picklist-id>yesNo</picklist-id>
  </field-definition>

If you have multiple application templates, you will need to add this to each template if you want to have the same features across all.

Step 2 – Create the rule

Create the rule for the application template configuration you have updated, again you will need to do this for each template.  A certified recruitment consultant should do this.

Step 3 – Assign the rule in Manage Recruiting Rule

Assign the rule to the correct application template as shown below again you will need to do this for each template. A certified recruitment consultant should do this.

Step 4 Update the Onboarding integration Setup

Update as shown.

Results

We have two candidates, one internal and one external, if we try to initiate onboarding from recruitment you will get this message. 

Why would you want to do this for an external?  One reason would be that they have been hired very quickly and not  have enough time for onboarding and therefore allowing you to hire them from recruitment direct into Employee Central

 

Note that Jack Williams is an internal employee and has also been sent to MPH.  For internal candidates once the transaction is completed you can still trigger the onboarding process.  What is good about this process is it drives consistency.  If you have concurrent employment and global assignments enabled candidates for these processes are sent to MPH before they trigger onboarding.  By treating internal applicants this way, it means everyone goes to MPH thus creating a consistent process. 

Note if they do not appear in MPH this may be due to the fact you need an offer approval please see this article.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management 2511 Release Key Innovations
entry.content:
1. Additional Supported Master Data Entities for Company Code Determination (CIM-2637)

With this feature, master data for the entity “Plant” is now supported and can be used to determine the Company Code for supplier invoices. For incoming invoices in which the buyer is a plant in the connected backend system, the plant master data, which includes the plant name and address, can be used to determine the company code. This feature allows for a more accurate company code determination process.

This is important because many organizations operate multiple plants, each potentially aligned to a different company code. Historically, mapping invoices to the right company code in such dynamic environments could be challenging, leading to manual corrections and delays. By incorporating plant master data directly into the automated company code determination process, we are enabling:

  • Greater Accuracy:  Ensures invoices are consistently mapped to the correct entity, minimizing errors.
  • Enhanced Automation:  Reduces manual intervention for company code assignment, saving time for AP teams.
  • Improved Compliance:  Strengthens audit trails and alignment with organizational structures in SAP backend systems.

When a supplier invoice is received, SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management now checks to determine if the invoice was issued to a specific plant. If so, it retrieves the corresponding plant master data and uses this information to map and assign the relevant company code automatically.  This new logic integrates seamlessly with existing backend system connectivity, further optimizing end-to-end invoice processing.

2.  Display of G/L Account, Cost Center, WBS Element Descriptions in Invoice Object Page while in Read-Only Mode (CIM-3080)

With this release, the G/L account, cost center and WBS element descriptions are now displayed on the invoice object page while displaying the invoice in read-only mode.  This provides clarity into essential details of an invoice and makes these details readily available to the user.  As organizations look to streamline their processes, visibility into invoice details remains a priority.  

With this release, users can now view the descriptions for General Ledger (G/L) accounts, cost centers, and Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) elements directly on the invoice object page while in read-only mode. Previously, users only saw technical IDs or codes for these fields, which could require additional steps to understand how invoices were being allocated.

The inclusion of these descriptions brings several immediate benefits:

  • Greater transparency: Users quickly understand the purpose and allocation of costs without navigating away or referencing separate documentation.
  • Accelerated review and approval: Approvers and auditors can immediately verify invoice line allocations, supporting faster decision-making and compliance checks.
  • Reduced user effort and support queries: By displaying clear descriptions for financial objects, you cut down on user questions and misinterpretations.

When you open an invoice in read-only mode within the Invoice Object Page, the G/L account, cost center, and WBS element descriptions will appear alongside their codes, making it easier than ever to understand exactly how each line of the invoice is allocated.

3.  Receive Item Price Details from SAP Business Network (CIM-1360)

With this enhancement, the integration between SAP Business Network and SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management has been improved.  You can now benefit from the following additional information, automatically transmitted as part of invoices received through the integration:

  • Tax Codes for Invoices Generated via Purchase Order Flip: Tax codes are now captured and transferred for invoices that suppliers generate by flipping purchase orders into invoices on SAP Business Network. This enables more accurate tax calculation, compliance, and downstream reporting.
  • Commodity Codes at the Line Item Level: Each line item now carries its own commodity code, enabling more granular spend classification and reporting. This makes it easier for accounts payable, finance, and procurement teams to analyze spend by commodity and comply with regulatory or corporate reporting requirements.
  • Charges and Allowances: Additional financial elements such as charges (for example, shipping or handling fees) and allowances (such as promotional or volume discounts) are now included in the invoice data. This ensures that all cost elements are clearly communicated and mapped, reducing reconciliation issues and enabling more precise financial postings.

Customers leveraging the integration between SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management and the SAP Business Network will automatically begin receiving these enriched invoice details for new documents processed after the update. No additional configuration is required —making it easy for your organization to immediately benefit from the improved integration.

4. Creation of Recurring Invoices (CIM-2296)

This new feature enables users to automate and optimize the invoicing process for regular payments for regular payment scenarios such as rent, leases, subscriptions, and other repeat services by creating invoices from existing ones on a scheduled basis. This feature saves time, provides clear identification and tracking of recurring invoices.  It also includes an audit trail for changes. 

Managing recurring payments manually can be time-consuming and error prone. Finance teams often must replicate invoice data or set reminders to issue the same invoice each billing cycle, increasing the risk of mistakes or missed payments. With our new Recurring Invoice feature, these pain points are a thing of the past.

Key Benefits and Capabilities include:

  • Seamless Automation: Users can now schedule the automatic creation of invoices at regular intervals based on existing invoice templates, ensuring timely billing and consistent cash flow management.
  • Efficient Tracking: Each recurring invoice is clearly identified and linked with its original source, providing both transparency and clarity through the lifecycle of the payment.
  • Comprehensive Audit Trail: Every change to a recurring series—whether schedule adjustments or template updates—is tracked for compliance and auditing, bolstering your company’s financial controls.
  • Time Savings: By removing repetitive manual work, your teams can focus on higher-value activities while ensuring billing accuracy and efficiency.
  • Simplified Administration: The new feature offers a centralized view and management capabilities for all recurring invoices making oversight easier than ever.

Getting started is simple. Users select an existing invoice as a template, define the recurrence schedule (for example: monthly, quarterly), and set up automatic generation going forward. Each generated invoice maintains a clear linkage to the original, making it easy to review the series and apply any needed updates.

5. Processing Limit Items (CIM-2296)

As businesses strive for greater agility and control in procurement, flexibility in handling diverse purchase order types becomes essential. With this new feature, you can now process an additional type of purchase order item in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management.  In addition to standard items, you can now also process limit items, which can be of the type material or service.

A limit item is a type of purchase order item that represents goods or services for which the exact quantity and price aren't known at the time of ordering but for which a total budget or spending limit has been defined.

Examples of Use Cases:

  • Ongoing consulting services billed by actual time spent, up to a maximum contract value
  • Maintenance or repair tasks where the extent of work isn’t fully predictable
  • Contingency materials, where you want to cap the amount spent but not specify exact quantities

This means AP teams and procurement professionals gain the following capabilities:

  • Seamless Invoice Processing: Invoices referencing limit items can now be processed directly within Ariba Central Invoice Management, streamlining AP workflows.
  • Greater Flexibility: Accommodate more business scenarios where the details of spending emerge over time, all while maintaining full control and compliance.
  • Enhanced Spend Management: Monitor and manage budgets on limit items to ensure spending stays within defined boundaries.

How Does It Help You?

  • Improved Efficiency:  Reduces manual workaround and off-system processing for variable-scope purchases.
  • Better Compliance:  Enforces contractual budget limits on incompletely specified purchases.
  • Consistent Insight:  Centralizes all PO types in one system for unified reporting and audit trails.

6. New Start and Step Conditions for Approval Workflow (CIM-3138)

With this release, you now have the ability to define start conditions that trigger approval workflows based on specific cost centers or Work Breakdown Structure (WBS) elements within your organization. Moreover, you can also configure these criteria as step conditions within your workflow—helping you direct the right invoices to the right approvers, at the right time.

What does this mean for you?

  • Greater Flexibility: Tailor your approval workflows with precision. For instance, initiate approvals only when invoices are allocated to certain cost centers, or escalate reviews at workflow steps when specific WBS elements are involved.
  • Optimized Control: Ensure compliance with your company’s financial governance by routing invoices for approval only when needed—streamlining processing, reducing bottlenecks, and improving visibility.
  • Adapt to Business Complexity: Easily support complex organizational structures and project-based spending scenarios by making workflows responsive to your evolving finance operations.

This new capability is accessible within your workflow configuration settings in Central Invoice Management. Detailed, step-by-step guidance is available in the release documentation.

7. Viewing Supplier Address Details in Value Help (CIM-3147)

As organizations continue to centralize and streamline their invoice management processes, having rapid and accurate access to supplier information becomes ever more crucial. With our latest Q4 2511 release, SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management takes a significant leap forward in usability with an enhanced feature: Viewing Supplier Address Details.

Based on customer feedback, we’ve expanded the functionality of the Value Help tool in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app. Now, when users select the value help icon for the “Invoicing Party” field—whether on the invoice list or invoice detail pages—they’ll find additional columns in the selection dialog. Alongside the familiar supplier codes and names, you can now view critical address details such as street, house number, and postal code.

With this release, you can now see the following improvements:

  • Quickly distinguish between suppliers or locations with similar or identical names.
  • Reduce errors in invoice assignment and processing.
  • Save valuable time by seeing all relevant supplier address details at a glance, directly within the intuitive value help dialog.

When working in the Manage Supplier Invoices Centrally app, click the value help (search icon) next to the Invoicing Party field. The expanded dialog now displays:

  • Supplier Name
  • Supplier Code
  • Street
  • House Number
  • Postal Code

This enhancement is available in all contexts—the invoice list view and the invoice details page—ensuring consistency and transparency wherever you need to select a supplier.

8. Company Code Determination – Support of Company Name, Address and Supplier Tax Fields (CIM-3168) 

With this feature, additional fields are supported for company code determination. Now, company name, company address and supplier tax will also be used to determine the company codes in addition to the existing fields.

Until now, company code determination in SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management relied on a set of established fields to accurately assign incoming invoices to the correct company code in your corporate structure. With the 2511 release, we’re expanding that capability – making it even easier to precisely route invoices based on your unique organizational and tax requirements.

Now, the following additional fields are included in company code determination:

  • Company Name
  • Company Address
  • Supplier Tax

By leveraging these new data points (in combination with your existing rules and fields), you’ll be able to handle more complex company structures and global tax scenarios with greater accuracy.

In today’s dynamic business environment, many of our customers manage a multitude of legal entities, branches, and tax jurisdictions. The correct assignment of company codes is crucial for streamlined, compliant invoice processing and downstream financial reporting.

With this enhancement, you can:

  • Support more nuanced and region-specific business rules for invoices.
  • Reduce manual intervention and the risk of mis-posting.
  • Minimize compliance risks associated with tax reporting and company code allocation.
  • Further automate and harmonize your invoice management processes, regardless of how your business evolves.

In summary, this feature now allows for a more accurate company code determination process.

These updates are designed to empower your invoice management teams with the tools they need. Stay tuned for more enhancements and continue to leverage SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management to drive business success!

Thank you for being part of the SAP Ariba community. We look forward to supporting your journey in delivering exceptional invoice management capabilities.

  • Register for the Early Release Series for 2511 release- Multi-registration link.

    • Feature related materials
      • SAP Ariba Connect - Release Readiness (Customers except CIM)
      • Readiness Community page (For CIM customers)
    • SAP Community for Intelligent Spend Management page
    • SAP Help Portal pages - Procurement  
    • What’s New

entry.title: Hot Topic: Joule Activation for SAP Cloud ERP (Public Edition)
entry.content:
SAP S/4HANA Cloud Expertise Service Team and SAP AI RIG team recently co-present a deep-dive session focused on enabling ‌Joule‌ - SAP’s generative AI copilot - for SAP Cloud ERP.

The agenda covered as below and feel free to access [Slides] [Recording]. 

  • Business AI capabilities and use cases
  • Joule’s technical architecture on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP)
  • Step-by-step activation process for S/4HANA Public Cloud
  • Q&A and live troubleshooting

1. Key Objectives‌

  • Demonstrate Joule’s value in streamlining business processes (e.g., sales order management, issue resolution in status check).
  • Guide participants through end-to-end setup using BTP booster, destinations, and identity management.
  • Equip partners to deploy Joule for customers with minimal friction.

2. Business AI & Joule Introduction‌

Joule Definition‌
  • SAP’s generative AI copilot embedded in cloud solutions to automate tasks, provide contextual insights, and reduce manual effort.
Primary Use Case‌:
  • Navigational support (e.g., finding apps without memorizing transaction codes)
  • Transactional support (e.g., creating insights cards, resolving incomplete sales orders)
  • Informational support (e.g., find SAP Help document for relevant business process)
Demo Highlight
  • Create Insights Cards with Joule
  • Check Sales Order Status with Joule‌:Joule identifies incomplete orders, highlights missing fields (e.g., payment terms), and guides users to resolve issues

3. Technical Architecture & Activation Flow‌

3.1 Core Components‌:

  • Joule Web Client‌ is embedded across SAP cloud solutions (e.g., SuccessFactors, S/4HANA)
  • BTP Subaccount‌
    • Hosts Joule instance
    • SAP Build Work Zone
    • connectivity services
  • Cloud Identity Services‌
    • Manages authentication (IAS)
    • Identity / role synchronization (IPS)
  • S/4HANA Cloud APIs‌: Data source for Joule’s responses.

3.2 Activation Steps‌:

Prerequisites‌:
  • BTP global account with Joule entitlements
  • S/4HANA system registered to BTP
BTP Subaccount Setup‌:
  • Create subaccount in preferred region/hyperscaler
  • Assign entitlements:
    • SAP Build Work Zone (foundation or standard edition)
    • Joule service
  • Establish trust to Cloud Identity Services tenant
  • Add S/4HANA domain to trusted destinations
Joule Booster Execution‌:
  • Guided setup for BTP formations.
  • Integrate S/4HANA, Build Work Zone, and Cloud Identity Services
Post-Booster Configurations‌:
  • Verify communication arrangements in S/4HANA (e.g., Digital Assistant Service - 0882).
  • Verify BTP Destinations
  • Verify SAP Build Work Zone Content for S/4HANA
  • Configure Identity Provisioning (IPS) to sync users/roles from S/4HANA to Build Work Zone
Validation‌:
  • Ensure Joule icon appears in S/4HANA Launchpad.
  • Test capabilities (e.g., querying open sales orders).

4. Critical Notes & Pitfalls‌

  • Trust Configuration‌: Ensure all solutions in a Joule formation use the ‌same Cloud Identity Services tenant‌.
  • Destination Errors‌: Verify hostnames, client IDs, and secrets in navigation service manually if not auto-generated.
  • Identity Provisioning‌: Ensure IPS jobs run successfully to propagate roles to SAP Build Work Zone.

5. Next Steps & Resources‌

Discovery Center Missions:
  1. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4538/4826/
  2. https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/missiondetail/4452/4738/
Support Channels‌:
  • SAP Community Blog for slides/recordings.
  • SAP Support for technical errors.
Upcoming Sessions‌:
  • Implement SAP Business AI for SAP Cloud ERP (Oct 27th)
  • Vietnam localization for implementation (Oct 28th)
